newsitem.title: UK: FOCUS-Tesco ups profit despite margins slip.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-Tesco ups profit despite margins slip.

text.p: Britain's leading supermarket group Tesco Plc on Tuesday reported a 10 percent rise in pre-tax profits and a continuing rise in sales at the start of the new trading year.
Tesco turned in pretax profits of 750 million pounds ($1.2 billion), up from 675 million and in line with expectations, while same store sales rose six percent in the first four weeks of this year.
"This is a good start in a competitive environment," the company said, reflected in a 7.5 pence rise in the company's shares to 360 by 1020 GMT.
Gross margins fell 0.4 percent to 5.8 percent last year, but deputy chairman David Reid said 0.3 points of the slippage was due to a petrol price war in Britain during the first half.
"We think low inflation will probably stay on through until about the autumn," Reid said in a telephone interview.
"We are anticipating next year to be a stabilising picture on margins...petrol margins are recovering and there seems to be some reasonable stability in food prices currently."
Maintaining gross margins would be the key during the current year, he said.
"I think it will still be very competitive. I think the noise level will still be high...I think you can see that just from the various promotions that are going on."
Reid said Tesco aimed to launch a credit card in early July as a first step in its financial services venture with Royal Bank of Scotland with other products to follow.

Tesco hoped that its recent purchase of Irish supermarkets from Associated British Foods (ABF) for 630 million pounds would see a return on capital on a depreciation basis of around 15 percent compared with around nine percent on the acquisition cost.
He said the company's operations in Hungary, where it has bought control of Global T.H. were showing strong sales growth.
"Like for like sales...last year were up 37 percent...so that's why we're there."
He said even allowing for inflation of around 19 percent, it was a strong performance. Tesco plans to open six to eight new stores in Hungary in 1998 after one in Budapest this year.
Reid said the transition of management with Lord MacLaurin stepping down as chairman later this year, was proceeding very smoothly and the new team would provide "more of the same."

He said that would include more customer initiatives based on "better prices, improved service, working very hard with ClubCard...further new products and particularly also more money going into refits and extensions."
Tesco aims to open 26 stores in Britain this year totalling some 600,000 sq feet (55,700 sq metres) along with some 200,000 sq feet (18,500 sq metres) of extensions. ($ = 0.614 British Pounds)
